Dear Mrs. Fernandez:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report and 2022C0108005, a first provisional license is
recommended, and a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan
is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 Indicate how continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 For repeat noncompliances identify why the previous CAP was
unsuccessful.
 Be signed and dated.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (866) 685-0006.

ALLEGATION:
Youth A has been without their psychotropic medications for the past week. This is a
repeat issue.
Youth B had been out of his prescribed medications multiple days prior to 01/06/22.
INVESTIGATION:
This complaint was originally received, on 12/21/21, as transferred for investigation.
The allegations noted the following,
Youth A (17) resides at Methodist Children's Home Society. Youth A is
prescribed psychotropic medications. He is diagnosed with Attention-
deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), Oppositional defiant disorder (ODD),
emotional impairment, cognitive impairment, and Reactive Attachment Disorder
(RAD). Youth A has not been given his 4PM psychotropic medications at
Methodist Children's Home Society. He has been without this medication for the
last week. Methodist Children's Home Society has had issues with staff leaving.
Upper management at Methodist Children's Home Society was not aware that
Youth A has been without his medication for the last week. Youth A's
medications were never put on the facility log to be refilled. In November 2021,
there was a similar incident with Youth A not getting his medications at Methodist
Children's Home Society.
I interviewed the complainant via phone, on 12/21/21, and confirmed the information
in the allegations.
3

I interviewed Youth A’s Foster Care Worker via phone, on 12/21/21. The Foster
Care Worker reported having visited with Youth A earlier in the day, on 12/21/21,
and found that he was not receiving his 4:00pm medication. The Foster Care Worker
said that she had reached out to the Family Transition Coordinator (FTC) and
Director 2 with this concern. The Foster Care Worker reported that there is a safety
plan in place for contacting her and others in the event that Youth A is not given his
medication, but this was not done. The Foster Care Worker reported concerns
related to potential behavioral issues when on home passes with his mother, if Youth
A is not getting his medications as prescribed. The Foster Care Worker said that
Director 2 stated she would address the medication issue in November, when Youth
A did not receive all of his medications another time, but Director 2 has not.
I met with Director 1 at the facility, on 12/21/21. Director 1 reported that Director 2
has been responsible for overseeing the residents’ medications while the facility
hired a new nurse. Director 1 reported that the new nurse was hired and just started
yesterday. Director 1 said that she looked at the medications and also found Youth A
had missed medication. Director 1 said that a meeting was held yesterday with her,
the Nurse, and Director 2 to discuss this. The Nurse is following up with the
pharmacy to rectify the issue.
I met with the Nurse at the facility, on 12/21/21. The Nurse confirmed that she just
started the day prior but had been told about the medication issue for Youth A. The
Nurse confirmed that the 4:00pm medication was the only one that was out. She
called the pharmacy while I was present and confirmed that the medication was
going to be delivered that day and coordinated with the pharmacy to have the
medication delivered earlier than normally scheduled, so that Youth A would have it
for his home pass that day.
I interviewed Director 2 at the facility, on 12/21/21. Director 2 has been overseeing
medications/medical for residents while the facility hires a new nurse to replace the
one who resigned. Director 2 reported that she does go through the Medication
Administration Records (MARs) but noted the last time she did was on 12/03/21.
Director 2 reported that medications were ordered 12/09/21 but Youth A’s 4pm
medication was not in there. He had six doses left. Director 2 said that she emailed
the pharmacy to advise of the situation. Director 2 said that Youth A’s Foster Care
Worker then reported Youth A was not getting his medication and when Director 2
checked, she found that to be true. Director 2 called the pharmacy and was told they
didn’t fill the prescription because they needed a new prescription from the doctor.
Director 2 said she then called the doctor and got a new prescription yesterday,
which was to be filled today, 12/21/21. Director 2 said that she did not know why
there was a gap in the medications.
The MARs were reviewed with Director 2 and the code “physically unable to take”
was entered by staff beginning 12/14/21, which would have been the day he ran out
of medication. This entry continued on the MARs though 12/21/21, with the
4

exception of 12/17/21. Director 2 said that staff would put this entry because there
were none of that medication remaining.
On 01/11/22, a second complaint was reported to DCWL related to medication
administration and dispensing. This complaint noted the following,
I was copied on an email on 1/6/22 from Youth B’s mother to facility case
manager (FTC) stating that Youth B had been out of his prescribed morning
medications for several days. Youth B is prescribed several meds, including
those for psychiatric reasons. On 1/7/22, I received an email from the Nurse
confirming that Youth B has been out of his medications for several days. Youth
B is placed by his parents, at Methodist, funded by Medical Subsidy through
AGAO.
I interviewed Complainant 2 via phone, on 01/10/22. Complainant 2 reported being
advised of this medication issue from a string of emails sent to her. The emails
included Youth A’s mother’s communication with the facility FTC related to
medications not being provided to Youth A. Complainant 2 forwarded the emails for
my review.
Documentation reviewed for the investigation includes the following,
 Medication Administration Records for Youth A for December: Out of one
4pm medication from 12/14/21-12/21/21. Missing documentation of
dispensing one or more doses, for Youth A, on four different medications.
Total of seven doses of mediations missed in December.
 Medication Administration Records for Youth B for December and January.
Multiple doses of five different medications had no documentation of being
dispensed for Youth B in December. “Physically unable to take” and “out of
meds” was noted by staff for three medications for Youth B from January 1-
January 7. On January 14, 2022, none of Youth B’s evening medications
were logged as dispensed and no reason provided for missing them.
 Emails provided by Complainant 2.
o 01/06/22 email from Youth B’s mother to the FTC noting Youth B
reported he wasn’t getting his morning medication for a few days
because they were out, and also an evening medication was out. The
email referenced this happened once before.
o 01/07/22 responding email from the FTC noting that medications were
ordered and should be received prior to the home pass for the same
day.
o 01/07/22 responding email from Youth B’s mother inquiring about
some details related to the missing medications.
o 01/07/22 responding email from the FTC noting that the nurse was
advised of the medications being out on 01/07/22 but did not know how
many days he had been out.
o 01/10/22 responding email from Youth B’s mother noting that she did
not have all of his medication for the previous weekend because the
staff said they didn’t have any more.
5

 Facility’s medication administration policy
 Youth A’s safety plan, dated 11/08/21. The plan states that Youth A will have
access to the phone to inform him Foster Care Worker if he misses
medication. Youth A will report concerns to a supervisor or his FTC. The
Foster Care Worker will follow up on concerns with Methodist staff and
management.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written health
service policies and procedures addressing all of the
following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
(g) Methods for dispensing medication when the
resident will be off site.
ANALYSIS: The facility is in violation as the documentation provided by the
facility, for both Youth A and Youth B, showed that not all
medications were dispensed as prescribed. It also appears that
the facility did not ensure that all medications were provided for
Youth B for a home pass, based on the emails exchanged
between the mother and the facility. Medication dispensing
issues have been found repeatedly over the past few months,
while the facility was in transition with nurses, so it is critical that
the facility administration ensure oversight to this process to
avoid further violations.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
I advised Director 2 to document her reviews of the MARs for
future CAP compliance verification. Saving all the MARs does
not show that she reviewed them or acted when needed.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
